address: Grafengasse 9, I - 39040 Margreid an der Weinstrasse
notes:
Company email (January 2014):
"No, our wines do not contain animal ingredients.
No, our products are not manufactured anywhere else in the world."

Company email (January 2015):
A: "We don't put anything in our wines so yes they are ok for vegans"
Q: "I understand that there are no animal products in the wine, but are any of your wines filtered or fined using any animal products such as isinglass, casein, albumin, or gelatin?
A: "No."

Company Email:
"in our portfolio is the Nine Vines Rose 2009 and Organic Chardonnay 2009 both of which are Vegan Friendly Wines.
 
We also distribute Temple Bruer Wines-www.templebruer.com.au – all of the wines from this producer are Vegan friendly and also Organic."

Note from Anke (March 2013):
"I just contacted Binderer St. Ursula Weinkellerei GmbH to ask if their wine "le sweet filou" is vegan friedly.
They said it is! :) The German reply you can find attached in this email." [Please contact Barnivore if you would like a copy of the letter from the company.]

Company email (May 2012):
"Nuestros vinos no contienen productos de origen animal. En nuestros procesos de clarificacion y filtración se utilizan compuestos de origen mineral."

[Translation]: "Our wines do not contain animal products. In our process of clarification and filtracuión used mineral compounds."

Amaya's translation:
"If you don’t read Spanish, it says that the whites are not vegan, but the roses and reds are."
 
Company Email:
"Sustancias de origen animal se utilizan para la clarificación de los vinos, y en concreto de los blancos de esta casa. Todos los demas vinos: rosados y tintos puede consumirlos sin problemas. Tambien tengo que decirle que la sustancia utilizada en clarificación se elimina en la las diferentes filtraciones que sufre el vino antes de embotellarse, con lo cuál en el vino quedarían como mucho a nivel de trazas."

Company email (February 2012):
Translation: "The only component added throughout the process is used for conservation in order to prevent oxidation: SO2 as indicated on the label: Contains sulfites" [Company also answered that they don't use animal products as ingredients or for filtering]

Company email (May 2013):
"En nuestros vinos blancos no usamos procuctos de origen animal, solo se usan bentonitas(tierras) y proteínas de origen vegetal (guisantes) para la clarificaicon del vino, por lo tanto nuestos vinos son aptos para vegetarianos y veganos"

[Google translation] "In our white wines do not use animal procuctos, only used bentonite (land) and plant proteins (beans) for wine clarificaicon therefore our wines are suitable for vegetarians and vegans"

Company email (August 2011):
"I’ve been talking to our winemakers and I’ve been told that here in the winery we don’t use any kind of animal products during the winemaking process.
 
The only products we use during the clarification are:
 
PVPP: to avoid the colour evolution, PVPP (a polymer) is added to the wine which reacts with the unstable colouring matter
 
Bentonite: bentonite (clay) is added. The bentonite has the capacity of joining itself to the proteins."

address: Gral. Roca y Urquiza (5521) Villa Nueva
notes:
Company email (February 2013):
"As a vegetarian myself I am happy to confirm that we do not use any animal based ingredients in our wine-making processes. All we use for filtration and clarification is benthonite (basically sand) and therefore our wines are vegan fiendly :)"

4387701.region: Spania, Castilla y León, Ribera del Duero

notes:
Company email (January 2011):
"All Bonny Doon wines are currently vegan; we use no animal products in the winemaking process. Some wineries use albumin, milk, or isinglass as fining agents to clarify their wines, but we currently use only bentonite clay. 
We don't rule out the possibility of using these ingredients if a particular wine in a particular vintage really needed this treatment. However, our winery pioneered ingredient labeling, so if we ever did choose to use them, we would disclose the items used on the back label. (As you're probably aware, wineries are not required to list ingredients.)
You may be interested in this article on vegan wines that was published last week:
http://www.thekitchn.com/thekitchn/wine/vegan-wine-what-is-it-and-how-can-i-find-vegan-wines--136676
The article specifically names Bonny Doon Vineyard as a vegan-friendly winery."

Company Email:
"Bonny Doon Vineyard does not use any animal ingredients in our winemaking practices, and have not for at least five years. We use bentonite in the fining process, but not isinglass, milk, or albumin. While we don't rule out the possibility of using these if a wine truly needed it (each vintage presents its separate challenges), but if we were to use any, we would include them in our full-disclosure ingredient labeling on the back label."

Company Email (June 2007):
"Even though we try to be as ethical as viticultually possible, I'm sorry to say, our wines are for the most part not vegan.

Some of our red wines may be vegan as we normally do not filter or fine our reds. However, there are instances when we use either skim milk or egg whites as fining agents to remove microscopic particles that could cloud the wines. But to be on the safe side, our wines overall cannot be guaranteed vegan. 

Some of our red wines may be vegan as we normally do not filter or fine our reds. However, there are instances when we use either skim milk or egg whites as fining agents to remove microscopic particles that could cloud the wines. But to be on the safe side, our wines overall cannot be guaranteed vegan.
Company email:
Even though we try to be as ethical as viticultually possible, our wines are for the most part not vegan."

"Braida Brachetto d'Acqui can be tasted & enjoyed by Vegan !

"Braida " is a family run winery and " Braida Brachetto d Acqui" is only produced & bottled in our Estate in Rocchetta Tanaro www.braida.it ."

notes:
Update:
Our domestic products are not made with animal by-products; we do indeed use an animal by-product in the filtration of our sake. This product is used to help remove charcoal prior to filtration; and is not part of the sake. We will be testing persimmon juice in the near future here at our Folsom facility. Persimmon juice is the only settling agent used by our home office facilities. To be simply put, any of our sakes/wines from Japan, as well as our US-made Draft sakes would be untouched by animal products.

notes:
Company email (May 2013):
"Los vinos elaborados por Bodegas Marques de Riscal son elaborados a partir de uvas procedentes de nuestros viñedos y de proveedores de las localidades de Elciego, Navaridas, Leza y Laguardia, principalmente.

Durante el proceso de elaboración no se incorpora ningún tipo de aditivo, excepto sulfitos, con objeto de que no se desarrolle la actividad de microorganismos, que pudieran alterar la calidad de nuestros vinos.

No se emplea ningún otro aditivo, no necesitándose clarificantes ni estabilizantes por los periodos de crianza de nuestros vinos en barrica, realizándose estos procesos de forma natural"

[Google translation] "The wines produced by Bodegas Marques de Riscal are made ​​from grapes from our vineyards and suppliers Elciego localities, Navaridas, Leza and Laguardia, mainly.

During the development process does not incorporate any additives, except sulphites, to not develop the activity of microorganisms, which could alter the quality of our wines.

Does not use any other additives, not needing clarifying and stabilizing for the periods of aging of our wines in barrel, performing these processes naturally"

Company email (October 2011):
"I’m glad to inform you that the Winery Marqués de Riscal doesn’t use for the filtration or clarification of our wines any of the products mentioned in your email.

The clarification is a natural process and we make it by ageing our wines in barrels for a long period of time (between 24 and 26 months). Once the wines are stabilized we make a very simple filtration before bottling them. We try to avoid aggressive filtrations that only may damage the character of our wines."

Company email (September 2012):
"I am very pleased to inform you that Serego Alighieri and Masi don't use animal by-products, animal derivatives or any allergy causing products in the production of our wines. At Masi, we believe that only precise care and attention to detail in every phase of wine making, from the vineyard to the bottle, can produce top class wines. Similarly, only care for the environment throughout the whole production process makes for high quality sustainable production."

Company email:
"I wish also to reassure you: for years the Masi group has avoided using animal-based products or allergens in its production."

Babel fish translation:

Company email (October 2012):
"Our Vranac is NOT  containinig any of such ingredients you mentioned, and there are NOT ANY animal products used in the processing/filtration of the product (such as isinglass, gelatin, etc).

Also, our product IS NOT manufactured anywhere else in the world (by a sub-licensee, for instance) that might use a different processing system."

Company Email:
"I recently discovered your site thanks to Twitter and would like to invite you to learn about Querciabella, a biodynamic wine estate located in Tuscany's legendary Chianti Classico zone. We not only have the privilege of producing some of the region's most critically acclaimed wines, but also we pride ourselves in leading the way for conservationism in viticulture. What this means at Querciabella is that respect for the environment and animal life is central to the way we work during all phases of wine growing and production.

While Querciabella has long been a benchmark of sustainability, converting to organic viticulture in 1988 and subsequently transitioning to biodynamics in 2000, the winery's owner Sebastiano Cossia Castiglioni, an outspoken animal rights activist, decided to ban all animal-derived products from the estate in 2007. As a result of our rigorous 100% Vegan policy, we have eliminated the use of animal products not only from the cellar but from the vineyards as well, relying exclusively on the use of cover crops for soil management"

Company email (April 2013):
"Our wines are suitable for Vegan, all wines are allergen free and no use of any animal ingredients.
Our production is only based in Portugal – Douro Valley."

Company email (November 2011)

All of our sauvignon blancs are vegan every year. If we do need to fine our
sauvignon blancs which is necessary every three years or so then we will use
a vegan friendly product.

Unfortunately there is no hard and fast rule for the other varieties we
make. Every year different levels of bitterness are produced in the grape
skins and different treatments are used to make the best wine we can. 

As 2011 was a high phenolic (bitter) year the only other white wine we
produced without the use of milk products is Pioneer Block 9 Riesling 2011.

Company email (April 2013):
"Our wines only contain grapes and a tiny addition of sulphur before bottling.

Company Email (September 2014):

"We do not use animal products in any way in the production of our wines."

Company email (January 2014):
"There are no animal products used in the production of any of our wines and they are only produced by us."

Company email (October 2012):
"Most sake does not use gelatin finings, although we cannot determine what does and what does not, and there is no way to know from the label. Powdered active charcoal is used for fining of most Japanese sake . This is made from (as far as we know) wood and plants, but we cannot be sure about all stuff at all places. Sake called "muroka" is unfiltered and unfined so that would be a safe bet. 
 
We follow the traditional Japanese sake making technology whereby we do not use animal ingredients or products in our production of sake. As to the use of charcoal filter as referred to in the above website while we are not 100% sure as to and how the charcoal is manufactured but we understand that it is of wood/plant origin.
 
Our Go-Shu sakes are only manufactured in Penrith, NSW."

8020201.product_name: J & G Musso Crémant de Bourgogne Brut

notes:
Company Email:
"The wine making philosophy at Veuve Clicquot Ponsardin should reassure you. 
During the elaboration of our wines we only use product of mineral origin (e.g. bentonite, which is used to clarify the grape juice). We still use product like sulfites to stabilize the wine and  to avoid any problems of oxidation  of the Champagne. 
Moreover in Veuve Clicquot we never use any fining agents. We filter our wine only once at the end of the vinification just before bottling. For this filtration we use Kieselguhr which is a filtering agent coming from fossils of shells (only mineral). "

From their website:
"Question: Is champagne suitable for vegetarians?
 Answer: Absolutely! We do not use any animal or dairy products at any stage of our winemaking process."
